title: JESUS FORGIVES AND HEALS A PARALYSED MAN. Part 4
scripture_text:
A few days later, when Jesus again entered Capernaum, the people
heard that he had come home. They gathered in such large number that
there was no room left, not even outside the door, and he preached the
word to them, then some men came, bringing to him a paralysed man,
carried by four of them. Since they could not get him to Jesus because
of the crowd, they made an opening in the roof above Jesus by digging
through it and then lowered the mat the man was lying on. When Jesus saw
their faith, he said to the paralysed man, "Son, your sins are
forgiven." Now some teachers of the law were sitting there, thinking to
themselves, "Why does this fellow talk like that? He's blaspheming! Who
can forgive sins but God alone?" Immediately Jesus knew in his spirit
that this was what they were thinking in their hearts, and he said to
them, "Why are you thinking these things? Which is easier: to say to
this paralysed man, 'Your sins are forgiven,' or to say, 'Get up, take
your mat and walk'? But I want you to know that the Son of Man has
authority on earth to forgive sins." So he said to the man, "I tell
you, get up, take your mat and go home. He got up, took his mat and
walked out in full view of them all. This amazed everyone and they
praised God saying, "We have never seen anything like this!
devotional:
This story is about Jesus helping us to understand forgiveness.

We need to think as these Jews would have thought. The physical
healing signified the spiritual healing. In general, Jewish thinking was
that sickness and misfortune were the result of sin. Perhaps Jewish
teachers did not link all ailments to specific sins, but they did
understand that in some way such misfortunes were related to God's
favour being removed. The healing's that took place, even the
miraculous healing's of Jesus, indicated that the offences of the
persons had been removed and God's favour restored.

So, it would not have been shocking if after Jesus had healed the
paralysed man, he then said, "Your sins are forgiven." Everyone would
have understood that he was simply making an observation or giving
assurance of what God had evidently done. What threw everyone off was
pronouncing forgiveness before the healing. Why did he do that? He did
it to make the point that he wasn't simply pronouncing what he believed
God had done for the man or was about to do but that he himself was
forgiving the man's sins.

By reversing the order of healing and forgiving, he demonstrated that
he was more than a prophet given a word of insight by God, but that he
possessed the very divine prerogative to forgive. The authority to heal
signified the authority to forgive. As Jesus said in verse 10: But that
you may know that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive
sins\...."

The words, 'your sins are forgiven,' were more than a pronouncement;
they were an act performed by one with divine authority to do so.

When Jesus sees the paralysed man he says 'Son you sins are forgiven.'
At this time there was a strong belief that sickness and disability was
either the result of the persons sin or their parents sin. The Rabbi's
taught a person could sin in the womb before birth, see John 9:1-2. The
Scribes had created categories of people for whom they know God doesn't
like -- Gentiles, prostitutes, tax collectors, tanners, lepers,
shepherds, women who are barren, and people with disabilities and
deformities. So when the people saw this Paralytic man, they had him
categorised, they saw him as someone who was condemned, someone who
deserved to be disabled, someone who was being punished for his sin and
that may be one of the reasons why the crowd would not let him in. So
Jesus says in front of all the religious leaders, 'Son your sins are
forgiven.' In saying this Jesus was confronting the stereotypical
perceptions of illness and disability.

These professional theologians knew the hidden implication to which
the rest of the crowd were oblivious to. By claiming the ability to
forgive sins, Jesus was claiming to be equal to God himself. According
to Jewish belief, no man not even a Messiah---would have the authority
to forgive sins. In the teaching of the Pharisees, blasphemy was the
most evil sin to which any human being could stoop to. No wonder they
were both outraged and secretly delighted at the same time. This
dangerous new rabbi was trapped by his own words, public words that had
been uttered in front of many witnesses. Judaism had determined that
even the promised Messiah could not forgive sins. So, these scribes took
Jesus' assertion as an affront to God's majesty, if not an implied claim
to be God. In the Torah, insulting God's dignity was the primary basis
of blasphemy.

The word forgiveness is one of those words that is used a lot in
Christian circles. But I don't think we fully grasp it meaning or
implications.

'The word \"forgive\" is the Greek word aphiemi. It means to set free;
to let go; to release; to discharge; or to liberate completely. It was
used in a secular sense in New Testament times in reference to
cancelling a debt or releasing someone from the obligation of a
contract, a commitment, or promise. Thus, it means to forfeit any right
to hold a person captive to a previous commitment or wrong he has
committed. In essence, it is the picture of totally freeing and
releasing someone. A modern paraphrase of this Greek word would simply
be to let it go! This means you and I don't have the privilege of
holding people hostage to their past actions if they repent and ask us
to forgive them.' Rick Rener.
[https://renner.org/article/confront-forgive-and-forget/](https://renner.org/article/confront-forgive-and-forget/)
access 21/03/2025

In the ancient world when a slave was set free after the death of his
master sometimes the word aphiemi was used. Here is the important thing
in using this word for forgiveness the focus is not preparing us for
heaven but transforming how we live now. Forgiveness is about whether or
not we live in bondage and enslavement to sin here and now in this
life.
prayer: Father help me embrace the glories of being forgiven.
